results.notes: Collected what appears to be an “Ash Tree Bolete” but in the absence of any ash trees. Rather, a flush of a dozen or so of these mushrooms was growing in the vicinity of a huge old oak with maples nearby, at the edge of a mixed woodland. Ashes in our area are very rare having been decimated by the Emerald Ash Borer. Specimen appears typical for this species including some bluing at the base of the stipe after sectioning.

results.notes:
Large, growing in Maryland today in a plantation of Eastern White Pine (Pinus strobus). No other trees were within 100 yards.

There was a very fragile ring that disappeared by the time I got home. The volva was broken up into warts.

Spores are pictured. This was a very prolific spore producer. I randomly measured 25. Spore size ranged from 8.6 × 6.7 to 12 × 8.5 microns. The mean Q value was 1.49, range 1.28-1.67.

results.notes:
Under Abies, on the ground.
Cap 3 cms., dark brown,fibrillose and scaly. Gills adnate with paler fringed edges. Stem fibrillose with a swollen base. Brown spore deposit, smooth spores elliptic or bean shape; spores (11.9-13.7) x (4.8-5.5), pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia present, various shapes, with or without crystal at the apex.

notes_fields.Substrate: Litter and bark wood chip mixed with soil
notes_fields.Conditions: Rain all week, moderate temperature, late Autumn
notes_fields.Bruising: Staining blue, either barely at all or conspicuously, particularly the stems and caps which had blue blotches that remained when dried.
notes_fields.DNA: Says half way between Psilocybe angulospora and Psilocybe stuntzii. It’s closer to stuntzii.

results.notes: Found on large fallen Cedar Tree, between 3500-4000 ft elevation. Mushroom bruised easily when touched, starting with a light bluing within a minute then turning brown after several minutes. Tested KOH reaction, on cap surface no reaction. On cross section and pore surface there was an instant bright yellow reaction. The cross section had a light bluing color at the edges of the KOH droplet after several minutes as well.

results.notes:
Laricifomes officinalis 9/10/21 notes:
Location: Cayuse Pass, WA-elevation 2500ft.
Three separate Young fruit bodies on a fallen 2nd growth Douglas fir.
Very soft, mailable pore surface(easily poked my finger into it and left depression-note mark at lower left of front specimen). Pore surface and entire context easily scraped with fingernail. NON staining where handled/scraped.
Easily sliced a portion/sample off of a single specimen with my pocket knife to obtain a spore print and dehydrate sample for herbarium collection/sequencing. Rapid regrowth/healing will begin immediately and does not effect future production/growth spore drop here. I plan to monitor this group with growth updates for many years to come(as with many of my previous observations of this species).
Left the remainder to continue fruiting for years to come. Will monitor perennial growth of all specimens to maturity(granting no one harvests them).

Interior/context: concentrically banded with 2 prior seasons of pore layer production(2 distinct visible rings in side/interior view after being sliced open). Once specimens take on a flat bottom, the perennial growth rings are then counted from the bottom only-at this stage they are counted vertically from interior center outward. These have dropped spores for 3 seasons.
Pore layer visibly separate from the rest of interior(light creamy yellow pore layer tubes-appear like dense paintbrush strands from side cut view).
Friable/mailable flesh(easily separated from interior(like soft blue cheese between fingers).
Taste: Extremely bitter and when tasted the flesh dissolved quickly on tongue(as with all the 20+ collections of Laricifomes officinalis I’ve tested over the years.

I Immediately spore printed the fruiting body on a glass slide upon arriving home. Left to print overnight.

Spore print: creamy light yellow.

Microscopy performed for spore images using my celestron scope(images included here).
Spores: very small.
Mostly all cylindrical, a few ellipsoid and ovoid. Smooth.
Sliced small specimen in half and dehydrated slices in dehydrator for over 12 hrs at 115F.

results.notes:
Collected under spruce.
Large size, 18 cms, aerolate, without scales. The cap is convex, with a sharp margin. The color is a light grey/brown with vinaceous tones, with lighter cracks.
The stipe was relatively short and off-center in this one.
The teeth, about 1 cm long, soft and fleshy and colored similar to the cap.
Flesh white, that, after a couple of minutes, turns grey with a violaceous tint (sepia, Hall).
Nodulose spores with about 14 small rounded warts. Including the ornamentation on these (8-8.5) x (7.8-8.0), Q aver= 1.06, thus almost round.
This looks like very close to Ronpast observation from Nama 2008, also from McCall, Idaho.

results.notes:
About 12.5 dozen fruitbodies growing gregariously in moss/short grass under old oaks. Based on the overall gestalt, I have collected this species at different spots on this property in the past (all associated with their own trees/groups of trees): obs 328651, obs 426871 and obs 427418. The first two observations in this list and the present collection were growing ~50 yards away from each other and form the apexes (apices) of a roughly equilateral triangle; #427418 is closest to the present observation, but still 100 yards away from it. With the possible exception of #427418, I could be dealing with the same organism that is shared by the overlapping rooting systems of many trees. Alternatively, all these collections could be the product of separate – either reproductively isolated or interbreeding – organisms.
None of these vouchers have been sequenced. I don’t know if DNA (ITS) can support or disprove the single organism theory even if single point mutations and ambiguities are present in the locus.

results.notes:
Beech, tulip poplar, populus.
Notes on this collection from Django Grootmyers:
“Growing singly on a Quercus rubra leaf. Cap 2.0 mm wide and 0.7 mm tall. Gills reduced. Stem hairy; eccentric; 1.9 mm tall and 0.2 mm wide. Clamps present in the pileipellis. Pileipellis composed of thick-walled hairs. Lamellar trama inamyloid with clamps. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 2-sterigmate and basally clamped. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (8.2) 8.4 – 10.1 (10.8) × (4) 4.2 – 5.1 (5.3) µm; Q = (1.8) 1.9 – 2.1 (2.3); N = 30; Me = 9.3 × 4.7 µm; Qe = 2.”

—

results.notes: These are spore prints made from the identical cap of an S. weaverae mushroom on two different colored backgrounds. Maddeningly, the white background suggests a much darker brown colored spore print while the black background suggests a lighter cinnamon-brown. Photographic variables, especially lighting and digital conversion also play a role in making the process of describing a spore print quite subjective. I understand this is a long-standing issue in mycology…how to choose an appropriate background on which to reproducibly document spore print color? Obviously, a clear background would probably be best but in trying to create a physical catalog of spore prints, I’ve settled on white and black glossy card stock because it’s easy to work with and store.

results.notes:
These mushrooms were posted to New Hampshire Mushrooms by Maria Elisa Borges. Found in Westborough, MA on 9/12/2021. I would have always called these Lactifluus hygrophoroides var. rugatus (now Lactifluus rugarus), but none of the varieties of L. hygrophoroides have forked gills! There are a few look-a-likes listed in North American Species of Lactarius and Milk Mushrooms of North America, but the only one with forked-gills is Lactarius lentus.
There are no images of Lactarius lentus in either book and the species is known only from Coker’s collections.
I also found no observations Lactarius lentus here on mushroom observer, but when I looked through observations of Lactifluus hygrophoroides I was able to find one with forked gills pretty quickly, and I’m sure there’s more. I haven’t looked through observations of Lactifluus rugatus yet, but I expect to find even more observations with forked gills there based on the description of L. lentus which has half to a third of the margin strongly rugose. I believe that Lactarius lentus is much more common than believed and has just been mislabeled as L. hygrophoroides and L. rugatus all this time. Either that, or it’s actually one of those species, and they actually can have forked gills…but I think this is unlikely since spore measurements are the same for L. hygrophoroides and L. rugatus but different for L. lentus in “North American Species of Lactarius”.
Before digging deeper into Russula and Lactarius this year, I never checked my L. Hygrophoroides to see if they had forked gills. I had already identified my find and never knew about the look-a-likes. Does anyone check them for forked gills? Could L. lentus be more common then we thought and have just been mislabeled ever since Coker’s collections over 100 years ago?
